contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox company | company_name = Harry & David | company_logo = [[File:Harry and David logo.png|200px]] | company_slogan = | location = [[Medford, Oregon|Medford]], Oregon, [[United States|US]] | key_people = | num_employees = | industry = | products = | homepage = [http://www.harryanddavid.com harryanddavid.com] }} '''Harry & David''' is an [[United States|American]] company that was founded in 1910, when Seattle hotelier Samuel Rosenberg purchased {{convert|240|acre}} of [[pear]] orchards in [[Medford, Oregon|Medford]], [[Oregon]].<ref name=OEarticle>{{Oregon Encyclopedia|harry_david|author=Jeff LaLande}}</ref> His sons, Harry and David, took the company over upon his death in 1914.<ref name=OEarticle/> The company is best known for beginning the business of [[mail order]] [[direct marketing]] of [[fruit]], especially through its "Fruit-of-the-Month Club." Their "Harry & David" brand specializes in high-end gift baskets and holiday gift towers. The company is owned by private investment firms [[Bruce Wasserstein|Wasserstein]] & Company<ref name=NYer01/> and [[Highfields Capital Management]],{{Citation needed|date=March 2012}} who bought the company in 2004. In 2005, Wasserstein and other investors took out dividends exceeding $100 million, and charged millions more in "management fees."<ref name=NYer01/> Harry and David had added [[Jackson & Perkins]], a mail-order [[rose]] marketer, to its brands in 1966. It sold Jackson and Perkins to an outside group of investors for $49 million in 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bizjournals.com/portland/stories/2007/04/02/daily4.html |title= Harry & David sells Jackson & Perkins |work= Portland Business Journal |date=April 2, 2007}}</ref> In 2008, Harry and David announced it acquired both catalogue-marketer Wolferman's from Williams Foods<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS213313+15-Jan-2008+PRN20080115 |title= Harry & David Holdings, Inc. Acquires Wolferman's, Leading Multi-Channel Marketer| publisher=[[Reuters]]| work= Press Release | date=January 15, 2008| accessdate=2010-12-16}}</ref> and Cushman's, a family-owned marketer of citrus and specialty foods.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS225077+11-Aug-2008+PRN20080811|title= Harry & David Holdings, Inc. Announces Acquisition of Cushman Fruit Company| publisher=[[Reuters]]| work= Press Release | date=August 11, 2008 | accessdate=2010-12-16}}</ref> Harry and David defaulted on its debt in 2011, also terminating its employee pension obligations.<ref name=NYer01>{{cite web |url= http://www.newyorker.com/talk/financial/2012/01/30/120130ta_talk_surowiecki|title= Private Inequity|work=[[The New Yorker]]|author= [[James Surowiecki]] | date=January 30, 2012 | accessdate=2012-01-23}}</ref> The company filed for [[Chapter 11]] [[bankruptcy]] on March 28, 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.usatoday.com/money/industries/retail/2011-03-28-harry-david-bankruptcy.htm|author=Bruce Horovitz|title= Harry & David seeks Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection| publisher=[[USA Today]]| date=March 28, 2011 | accessdate=2011-03-28}}</ref> The company completed its bankruptcy reorganization in September 2011.<ref>{{cite news|last=Goldfield|first=Robert|title=Harry & David emerges from bankruptcy|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/portland/news/2011/09/14/harry-david-emerges-from-bankruptcy.html|accessdate=3 November 2012|newspaper=Portland Business Journal|date=September 14, 2011}}</ref> In November 2012, the company announced it had started a winery with plans for nine wines.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stevens|first=Suzanne|title=Harry & David launches winery|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/portland/morning_call/2012/11/harry-david-launches-winery.html|accessdate=2 November 2012|newspaper=Portland Business Journal|date=November 2, 2012}}</ref>
